title: Management Accounting Theory and Techniques
headline: This free online course provides an overview of the financial methods used to plan organisational strategy.
description: In this course, you will explore management accounting theory that enables value creation, preservation and reporting to manage performance. We guide you through forecasting techniques that inform the budgetary process. In addition to the theory behind budgeting and controlling performance, we also discuss linear programming. Finally, we consider risk and uncertainty and how to account for risk in decision-making.
courseDescription:
'Management Accounting Theory and Techniques' is a course designed to provide an overview of accounting-based theories and procedures used to create and preserve organisational value. These methods form part of the management accounting toolbox to inform an organisation's strategy execution. The course guides you through essential theories and techniques at various decision-making levels.

First, we consider using the budgetary process to deploy an organisation's strategy by interpreting the vision, mission and strategic objectives to formulate medium and short-term plans. We then discuss how performance is managed through budgetary control principles, involving identifying critical success factors and key performance indicators based on organisational strategy. Finally, we look at risk and uncertainty in the short term and how to account for and analyse risks in planning and operational activities.

The course participants will become acquainted with core theories and tools used to enact organisational strategy, analyse and control the strategy execution at an operational level and report on outcomes. You will also understand how to account for and report on risks associated with decision-making. So enrol today and start developing your toolbox to gain a competitive advantage.

slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module, you will be able to:
    • Define budgeting and the various elements of budgets.
    • Discuss budgetary control and the use of budgets in performance management.
    • Describe the purpose of budgeting and the advantages of using budgets.
    • Explain the use of forecasts in the budgetary process.
    • Compute fixed and variable costs using statistical methods.
    • Discuss the use of linear programming in resource allocation and planning.
    • Contrast the different risk criteria used in decision-making involving uncertainty.
    • Describe the fundamental methods used to analyse risk for decision-making and planning. 

  • Terminology 

  • Budget 
    Quantitative representation of a plan for a defined period of time. It may include planned sales volumes and revenues; resource quantities, costs and expenses; assets, liabilities and cash flows.

    Functional budgets and the master budget 
    A master budget consolidates the departmental or activity budgets for all the responsibility centres within an organisation. The structure of a budget depends on the operating model employed by the organisation. 

    Principal budget factor 
    The principal budget factor is identified as the input or process that is the primary organisational limiting factor. Once the principal budget factor is identified,  the associated budget is prepared as a basis for the preparation of all other budgets. 

    Cash budgets and cash flow forecasts 
    A cash flow forecast is an estimate of cash receipts and payments for a future period under existing conditions. Cash budgets are used to: assess and integrate operating budgets; plan for cash shortages and surpluses, and compare with actual spending. There are two methods that can be used to create a cash budget: a receipts and payments forecast; or a balance sheet forecast.

  • Forecasting Techniques

  • Forecasts in budgeting
    Budgets are based on forecasts. Forecasts might be prepared for: the volume of output and sales, sales revenue (sales volume and sales prices), and costs.

    The purpose of forecasting in the budgeting process is to establish realistic assumptions for planning. Forecasts might also be prepared on a regular basis for the purpose of feedforward control.

  • Lesson Summary 

  • Management Accounting Toolbox:
    • Budgeting is an important technique for converting long-term strategies into short-term action plans.
    • A budget is a quantitative representation of a plan for a defined period of time. It may include planned sales volumes and revenues; resource quantities, costs and expenses; assets, liabilities and cash flows.
    • A master budget consolidates the departmental or activity budgets for all the responsibility centres within an organisation. 
    • The principal budget factor is identified as the input or process that is the primary organisational limiting factor.
    • A cash flow forecast is an estimate of cash receipts and payments for a future period under existing conditions.
    • A periodic budget represents the costs and revenues for a single period of time and is updated on a periodic basis.
    • A rolling budget is a budget that is continuously updated by adding a further accounting period (month or quarter) when the earliest accounting period has expired.
